intro: Solenandra sanctae-luciae, commonly known as the Saint Lucy's screw pine, is a flowering plant native to the island of Saint Lucia in the West Indies. It is a member of the Pandanaceae family and is characterized by its spirally arranged leaves and small, fragrant flowers. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are narrow and strap-like, often with a waxy texture, and it produces yellowish-green flowers that bloom in clusters. Solenandra sanctae-luciae is adapted to coastal environments and thrives in sandy, well-drained soils.
